                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | Status | Notes | Recommendation |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Resource Utilization** | | | | |
| Compute Resources (DSS Automation/Design/API Deployer Nodes, EMR, EKS) | Underutilized or idle instances/clusters | Unknown | The diagram shows these as central components, but does not provide details on their current compute utilization or operational patterns (e.g., if they run 24/7, if EMR clusters auto-terminate). | Implement Right-Sizing by monitoring CPU/memory utilization to match instance types to actual workload needs. Consider using AWS Compute Optimizer. Implement Scheduled Start/Stop for non-production DSS nodes during off-hours (evenings, weekends). For EMR, ensure auto-termination is configured for transient clusters. For EKS, implement Cluster Autoscaler and Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) to dynamically adjust worker node and pod counts based on demand. |
| Amazon Redshift | Idle or underutilized cluster | Unknown | Redshift can incur significant costs if not actively used or correctly sized for the workload. | Monitor Redshift cluster utilization (CPU, I/O, storage). If usage is intermittent, explore Redshift Serverless for pay-per-use, automatic scaling. For RA3 node types, utilize the Pause and Resume feature during idle periods. Consider workload management (WLM) and concurrency scaling for efficient resource use. |
| Amazon S3 | Inefficient storage tiering/lifecycle policies | Unknown | S3 Standard is the default but might not be cost-optimal for all data access patterns. | Implement S3 Lifecycle policies to automatically transition infrequently accessed data to lower-cost storage classes (e.g., S3 Standard-IA, S3 One Zone-IA, S3 Glacier Flexible Retrieval, S3 Glacier Deep Archive) based on access patterns. Consider S3 Intelligent-Tiering to automatically move data to the most cost-effective tier. Establish clear retention policies to delete old or unnecessary data. |
| Redundant Services | No obvious explicit redundancies from diagram | N/A | The architecture appears to be a single deployment within one Availability Zone, which might not offer high availability but is typically cheaper than a multi-AZ setup from a direct resource perspective. | N/A (No explicit redundant services identified for cost reduction within the diagram itself.) |
| **Pricing Models** | | | | |
| DSS Nodes (EC2-like) | On-Demand pricing for predictable workloads | Unknown | If these nodes have a consistent, predictable baseline usage, On-Demand pricing is more expensive. | Evaluate Savings Plans or Reserved Instances (RIs) for the DSS Automation/Design/API Deployer Nodes if their usage is stable and predictable for 1- or 3-year commitments. Look into Compute Savings Plans for overall EC2 spend. |
| Amazon Redshift | On-Demand pricing for predictable workloads | Unknown | Redshift cluster costs can be significantly reduced with commitment. | For predictable Redshift workloads, purchase Reserved Nodes to achieve substantial discounts compared to On-Demand pricing. |
| Amazon EMR | On-Demand pricing for transient/batch workloads | Unknown | EMR clusters can be composed of diverse instance types, making Spot Instances a viable option for certain nodes. | Utilize Spot Instances for EMR task nodes (and potentially core nodes if the workload is fault-tolerant) to reduce compute costs significantly. Leverage EMR Managed Scaling which can automatically use Spot Instances effectively. |
| Amazon EKS (Worker Nodes) | On-Demand pricing for predictable/bursty workloads | Unknown | The underlying EC2 instances for EKS worker nodes could benefit from commitment or spot pricing. | Implement Savings Plans or Reserved Instances for the predictable baseline load of EKS worker nodes. Integrate Spot Instances for stateless, fault-tolerant workloads running on EKS. Consider AWS Fargate for EKS for specific microservices to achieve serverless compute, offloading operational overhead and optimizing costs for bursty workloads (though potentially higher cost per vCPU/GB than optimized EC2 for sustained loads). |
| Data Transfer | Potential for excessive data transfer costs | Unknown | Data transfer costs can be significant, especially egress to the internet or across regions. | Minimize cross-AZ and cross-region data transfer where possible. Ensure data transfer within the same AZ is utilized. Consider using VPC Endpoints for communication with AWS services like S3 or Glue from within the VPC to reduce data egress to the public internet and improve security. |
| **Tagging & Budgeting** | | | | |
| Cost Allocation Tags | Absence of tagging strategy | Not Visible | Effective tagging is crucial for cost visibility, allocation, and chargeback. | Implement a comprehensive AWS tagging strategy for all resources (e.g., `Project`, `Environment`, `Owner`, `CostCenter`) to enable detailed cost allocation and reporting using AWS Cost Explorer. |
| Budget Alerts & Cost Monitoring | No explicit mention of cost monitoring/alerts | Not Visible | Lack of monitoring can lead to unexpected cost spikes and overruns. | Configure AWS Budgets with alerts for actual and forecasted spend against defined thresholds for the entire account or specific services/tags. Regularly review AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Billing dashboards to identify trends and anomalies. Consider enabling AWS Cost Anomaly Detection. |
| **Automation** | | | | |
| Resource Autoscaling/Scheduling | Lack of dynamic scaling for compute resources | Not Explicitly Shown | Manual provisioning or static sizing often leads to over-provisioning or idle resources. | For DSS Automation/Design/API Deployer Nodes, implement Autoscaling Groups (ASG) to scale compute capacity up or down based on demand or scheduled actions. For EMR, ensure Managed Scaling is enabled. For EKS, use Cluster Autoscaler and Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) to ensure compute resources match actual pod demand. |
| EMR Cluster Management | Manual EMR cluster termination | Not Explicitly Shown | If EMR clusters are not automatically terminated after jobs complete, they incur unnecessary costs. | Configure auto-termination for Amazon EMR clusters immediately after jobs are finished or after a period of inactivity. Use Step Functions or other orchestration tools to manage the lifecycle of transient EMR clusters. |
| Consolidated Billing Benefits | Not applicable for single account view | N/A | The diagram shows a single AWS account architecture. | If this architecture is part of a larger organization, ensure it is part of an AWS Organization to benefit from consolidated billing and volume discounts. |
| Architectural Adjustments for Cost Efficiency | Public subnet for DSS nodes, potential for optimizing EKS workloads | Not Fully Optimized | DSS nodes in a public subnet might imply direct public access when only outbound internet connectivity is needed, and EKS workloads could be more cost-efficient with serverless options for some use cases. | If DSS nodes only require outbound internet access, move them to a private subnet and route outbound traffic via a NAT Gateway to enhance security and potentially manage costs if Elastic IPs are unnecessarily retained or high ingress traffic to public IPs occurs. For EKS, evaluate specific workloads for migration to AWS Fargate to remove the need for managing EC2 worker nodes and simplify operations, potentially optimizing costs for highly variable or intermittent workloads. |

central computation instances, but offers no indication of exact type (e.g., specific EC2 family/size), running schedule (e.g., 24/7 vs. intermittent), or whether they are actively utilized at optimal capacity. |  Optimize compute sizing: Continuously monitor CPU, memory, and disk I/O utilization to right-size instances. AWS Compute Optimizer can provide data-driven recommendations. Employ scheduled start/stop: For non-production or development DSS nodes, configure AWS Instance Scheduler or custom AWS Lambda functions to start and stop instances during defined business hours, eliminating costs for idle periods.  Leverage Auto Scaling: For DSS nodes that experience variable demand, configure Auto Scaling Groups (ASG) to dynamically adjust the number of instances based on demand, preventing over-provisioning during low-traffic periods.  |

Redshift clusters are charged per hour (or fraction) and by storage. | **Right-Size & Scale:** Continuously monitor Redshift cluster utilization (CPU, memory, disk I/O, query performance) using CloudWatch. If underutilized, consider a smaller node type or fewer nodes. If usage patterns are intermittent, explore **Redshift Serverless** for automatic provisioning and scaling of compute capacity, paying only for what you use, without managing clusters. **Reserved Nodes:** For predictable, sustained workloads, purchase Redshift Reserved Nodes for 1-year or 3-year commitments to achieve significant discounts over On-Demand pricing. **Pause and Resume:** If using RA3 node types, leverage the "Pause and Resume" feature for periods of inactivity (e.g., nights, weekends) to save on compute costs when the cluster is not actively querying data. **Data Lifecycle:** Ensure unnecessary data is purged or moved to S3 for long-term archival. |

                                              | Unknown      | The diagram shows these as central computation instances, but offers no indication of exact type (e.g., specific EC2 family/size), running schedule (e.g., 24/7 vs. intermittent), or whether they are actively utilized at optimal capacity. |  Optimize compute sizing: Continuously monitor CPU, memory, and disk I/O utilization to right-size instances. AWS Compute Optimizer can provide data-driven recommendations. Employ scheduled start/stop: For non-production or development DSS nodes, configure AWS Instance Scheduler or custom AWS Lambda functions to start and stop instances during defined business hours, eliminating costs for idle periods.  Leverage Auto Scaling: For DSS nodes that experience variable demand, configure Auto Scaling Groups (ASG) to dynamically adjust the number of instances based on demand, preventing over-provisioning during low-traffic periods.  |
| Amazon Redshift          | Idle or underutilized cluster                                                           | Unknown      | This means the Redshift cluster is already provisioned. The specifics of how well-utilized it is, what the data volume looks, and what are the actual demands are missing. Redshift clusters are charged per hour (or fraction) and by storage. | **Right-Size & Scale:** Continuously monitor Redshift cluster utilization (CPU, memory, disk I/O, query performance) using CloudWatch. If underutilized, consider a smaller node type or fewer nodes. If usage patterns are intermittent, explore **Redshift Serverless** for automatic provisioning and scaling of compute capacity, paying only for what you use, without managing clusters. **Reserved Nodes:** For predictable, sustained workloads, purchase Redshift Reserved Nodes for 1-year or 3-year commitments to achieve significant discounts over On-Demand pricing. **Pause and Resume:** If using RA3 node types, leverage the "Pause and Resume" feature for periods of inactivity (e.g., nights, weekends) to save on compute costs when the cluster is not actively querying data. **Data Lifecycle:** Ensure unnecessary data is purged or moved to S3 for long-term archival. |
| Amazon EMR               | Unused or over-provisioned clusters (if not auto-terminated)                            | Unknown      | Amazon EMR clusters, especially for batch processing, are often transient. If not configured for auto-termination, they can sit idle and accrue significant costs. | Ensure EMR clusters are configured for **auto-termination** after a period of inactivity or upon job completion. Utilize **EMR Managed Scaling** to dynamically add/remove instances based on workload needs. Implement **Spot Instances** for EMR task nodes (and potentially core nodes for fault-tolerant workloads) to significantly reduce compute costs. |
| Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS) | Over-provisioned worker nodes or inefficient pod scheduling | Unknown      | The diagram shows EKS, which runs on EC2 instances (worker nodes). Without proper scaling, these instances can be over-provisioned, leading to idle capacity. | Implement **Cluster Autoscaler** to dynamically adjust the number of EKS worker nodes based on pending pods. Utilize **Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA)** to scale the number of pods based on CPU/memory utilization or custom metrics. Consider **Vertical Pod Autoscaler (VPA)** to automatically adjust resource requests and limits for pods. For certain workloads (e.g., serverless microservices), evaluate **AWS Fargate for EKS** to remove the need for managing worker nodes entirely, paying only for pod resources. |
| Amazon S3                | Inefficient storage tiering or lack of lifecycle policies                               | Unknown      | Amazon S3 defaults to Standard storage, which is suitable for frequently accessed data, but may not be cost-optimal for data with different access patterns or retention requirements. | Implement **S3 Lifecycle policies** to automatically transition objects to lower-cost storage classes (e.g., S3 Standard-IA, S3 One Zone-IA, S3 Glacier Flexible Retrieval, S3 Glacier Deep Archive) based on their age or access frequency. Consider using **S3 Intelligent-Tiering** for data with unknown or changing access patterns, as it automatically moves data between tiers based on access. Define and enforce data retention policies to delete outdated or unnecessary data. |
| AWS Glue                 | Over-provisioned Data Processing Units (DPUs) or long-running jobs | Unknown      | AWS Glue jobs are billed by Data Processing Unit (DPU) hours. Inefficient job configurations or long-running Glue interactive sessions can lead to excessive costs. | **Optimize Glue Jobs:** Right-size DPUs for Glue jobs by monitoring job metrics and adjusting capacity based on actual processing needs. Configure **auto-scaling for Glue ETL jobs**. Implement **job bookmarks** to avoid reprocessing old data. Ensure interactive sessions are terminated when not in use. |
| External ML Services (SageMaker, Rekognition, Comprehend) | Potential for underutilized endpoints or model hosting | Unknown      | SageMaker, Rekognition, and Comprehend are billed per usage (e.g., inference, training, API calls). In SageMaker, endpoints might be over-provisioned or models hosted 24/7 when not needed. | For **Amazon SageMaker**, utilize **instance right-sizing** for training jobs. Implement **SageMaker Asynchronous Inference** for workloads that can tolerate latency, or **multi-model endpoints** to share compute resources. For infrequent inference, consider **SageMaker Serverless Inference**. Monitor usage of **Rekognition** and **Comprehend** APIs and ensure their use aligns with business value. |

                                                              | Unknown      | This means the Redshift cluster is already provisioned. The specifics of how well-utilized it is, what the data volume looks, and what are the actual demands are missing. Redshift clusters are charged per hour (or fraction) and by storage. | **Right-Size & Scale:** Continuously monitor Redshift cluster utilization (CPU, memory, disk I/O, query performance) using CloudWatch. If underutilized, consider a smaller node type or fewer nodes. If usage patterns are intermittent, explore **Redshift Serverless** for automatic provisioning and scaling of compute capacity, paying only for what you use, without managing clusters. **Reserved Nodes:** For predictable, sustained workloads, purchase Redshift Reserved Nodes for 1-year or 3-year commitments to achieve significant discounts over On-Demand pricing. **Pause and Resume:** If using RA3 node types, leverage the "Pause and Resume" feature for periods of inactivity (e.g., nights, weekends) to save on compute costs when the cluster is not actively querying data. **Data Lifecycle:** Ensure unnecessary data is purged or moved to S3 for long-term archival. |
| Amazon EMR               | On-Demand pricing for transient/batch workloads                         | Unknown      | EMR clusters can be composed of diverse instance types, making Spot Instances a viable option for certain nodes. The diagram doesn't specify if Spot is used. | Utilize **Spot Instances** for EMR task nodes (and potentially core nodes if the workload is fault-tolerant) to reduce compute costs significantly. Leverage **EMR Managed Scaling** which can automatically use Spot Instances effectively. |
| Amazon EKS (Worker Nodes)| On-Demand pricing for predictable/bursty workloads                      | Unknown      | The underlying EC2 instances for EKS worker nodes could benefit from commitment or spot pricing. The diagram does not specify pricing models. | Implement **Savings Plans** or **Reserved Instances** for the predictable baseline load of EKS worker nodes. Integrate **Spot Instances** for stateless, fault-tolerant workloads running on EKS. Consider **AWS Fargate for EKS** for specific microservices to achieve serverless compute, offloading operational overhead and optimizing costs for bursty workloads (though potentially higher cost per vCPU/GB than optimized EC2 for sustained loads). |
| Data Transfer            | Potential for excessive data transfer costs                             | Unknown      | Data transfer costs can be significant, especially egress to the internet or across regions. The diagram doesn't provide data transfer details. | Minimize cross-AZ and cross-region data transfer where possible. Ensure data transfer within the same AZ is utilized. Consider using **VPC Endpoints** for communication with AWS services like S3 or Glue from within the VPC to reduce data egress to the public internet and improve security. |
| **Tagging & Budgeting**  | Cost Allocation Tags                                                    | Not Visible  | Effective tagging is crucial for cost visibility, allocation, and chargeback, which cannot be inferred from the diagram. | Implement a comprehensive AWS tagging strategy for all resources (e.g., `Project`, `Environment`, `Owner`, `CostCenter`) to enable detailed cost allocation and reporting using AWS Cost Explorer. |
| Budget Alerts & Cost Monitoring | No explicit mention of cost monitoring/alerts                   | Not Visible  | Lack of proper cost monitoring and budget alerts can lead to unexpected cost spikes and overruns. | Configure **AWS Budgets** with alerts for actual and forecasted spend against defined thresholds for the entire account or specific services/tags. Regularly review **AWS Cost Explorer** and **AWS Billing** dashboards to identify trends and anomalies. Consider enabling **AWS Cost Anomaly Detection** to get alerted on unusual spending patterns. |
| **Automation**           | Resource Autoscaling/Scheduling                                         | Not Explicitly Shown | Manual provisioning or static sizing often leads to over-provisioning or idle resources for EC2-like services. | For DSS Automation/Design/API Deployer Nodes, implement **Autoscaling Groups (ASG)** to scale compute capacity up or down based on demand or scheduled actions. For EMR, ensure **Managed Scaling** is enabled. For EKS, use **Cluster Autoscaler** and **Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA)** to ensure compute resources match actual pod demand. |
| EMR Cluster Management   | Manual EMR cluster termination                                          | Not Explicitly Shown | If EMR clusters are not automatically terminated after jobs complete, they incur unnecessary costs. | Configure **auto-termination** for Amazon EMR clusters immediately after jobs are finished or after a period of inactivity. Use Step Functions or other orchestration tools to manage the lifecycle of transient EMR clusters. |
| Consolidated Billing Benefits | Not applicable for single account view                                  | N/A          | The diagram shows a single AWS account architecture, so consolidated billing within an AWS Organization is not visible or directly applicable here. | If this architecture is part of a larger organization, ensure it is part of an **AWS Organization** to benefit from consolidated billing, aggregated usage for volume discounts, and simplified cost management across multiple accounts. |
| Architectural Adjustments for Cost Efficiency | Public subnet for DSS nodes, potential for optimizing EKS workloads | Not Fully Optimized | DSS nodes in a public subnet might imply direct public access when only outbound internet connectivity is needed, and EKS workloads could be more cost-efficient with serverless options for some use cases. | If DSS nodes only require outbound internet access, move them to a private subnet and route outbound traffic via a **NAT Gateway** to enhance security and potentially manage costs if Elastic IPs are unnecessarily retained or high ingress traffic to public IPs occurs. For EKS, evaluate specific workloads for migration to **AWS Fargate** to remove the need for managing EC2 worker nodes and simplify operations, potentially optimizing costs for highly variable or intermittent workloads. |
